column5: I wrote the MNR about this subject, because of an earlier thread that had questions. My original letter is on the bottom. This is their reply: Hello,Thank you for your inquiry.A hook includes a single-pointed or multiple-pointed hook on a common shaft but does not include a snagger or spring gaff. The number of hooks includes any single-pointed or multiple-pointed hooks that are part of a lure. A fishing line must not have more than four hooks attached. Therefore, it is legal to use a stinger hook.You may not catch a fish by impaling or snagging it with a hook through any part of the body other than the mouth - any fish hooked in this way must be released immediately.I hope you have found this information helpful. If you require further assistance, please contact the Natural Resources Information Centre at 1-800-667-1940.Regards,NRIC web reader - DCOntario Ministry of Natural ResourcesNatural Resources Information Centre300 Water Street, 3rd Floor, North TowerPeterborough, ON K9J 8M51-800-667-1940TTY: 1-866-686-6072Fax: 705-755-1677[email protected]Messages sent by email are not secure. Alternatively, you can phone 1-800-667-1940 between 8:30AM and 5:00PM, Monday through Friday.-----Original Message-----From: Sent: April 16, 2014 6:28 PMTo: NRIC, MNR (MNR)Subject: HelloWe come up to Cedar Lake, Ontario, 22 miles north of Vermillion Bay, 2 times a year. We have never used stinger hooks, because years ago we were told that it was illegal.We would like to find out the truth, because we are having a big discussion on a Walleye blog. They all say that it is legal to use a stinger hook on a jig. Please give me an accurate answer that I can share, and so that I know.Thank you very much for your time,
